body: Would this mean that the R magic requires knitr? As far as I know, I don't have that installed.

Yes, it would make a dependency on knitr which is installable with "install.packages('knitr')". I modified the code to check for knitr and use the original R magic if the package is not available. By default, it will use knitr, and emits a warning if it is not found.

I thought that mimicking knitr's output would be attractive to R users in that knitr has replaced Sweave as a tool
to generate "rich" documents with R.

As far as performance goes, I haven't tested it heavily so I don't have a good answer. In principle, I can't see a big loss, it would depend on how long knitr takes to evaluate a code chunk versus the regular R interpreter. If the code chunk is short and not producing huge numbers of outputs, I can't see how there would be a big hit. 

Does anyone have an example of something knitr is very slow at?
FYI this does not merge cleanly anymore.

Just pasting an email thread I had offline with Fernando....
- Regarding installing knitr -- I had added an Rinstall magic to install packages with a fixed CRAN mirror (configurable). Generally speaking, installing R packages is very smooth.
- I suppose it also wouldn't hurt to just have an additional magic %%knitR that has this functionality but I thought that might be adding too many magics.
- It's not really functionality that will be lost, it is "feel". With something like the knitr version of the magic, it feels more like interacting with an R console.

Jonathan 

P.S. Naras (who teaches the statistical computing class) also asked me yesterday if you might give a lecture in his class, though it sounds like you're very busy.

On Thu, Dec 6, 2012 at 12:27 AM, Fernando Perez Fernando.Perez@berkeley.edu wrote:
Hey,

 by all means please post this feedback on the GH issue, just
copy-paste it straight in.  It will help the review process in case
others pitch in. Sorry I can't do it but I'm nearly computer-less and
in Hawaii for a few more days, so I won't be able to do anything on
github until next week, I'm afraid.

If it's not possible to keep the knitr dependency off without losing
significant functionality, so be it.  But in that case, it should
provide a nice and useful error message to the user when knitr is
absent, hopefully with some indication of what to do to get it going
(as I can imagine this being used by python users who need a bit of R
but don't know the R packaging/installation tools well).

Cheers,

f

On 12/5/12, Jonathan Taylor jonathan.taylor@stanford.edu wrote:

> I just wanted to add that I'm trying to press a little because I have
> several R users who have asked for examples and I think it would be nice
> if, to them, it felt more like Rstudio.
> 
> By the way, can you come down next quarter to give a talk to our group
> meeting? We might also try to schedule you to give a class in our STATS290
> (see http://stat.stanford.edu/courses)
> 
> Jonathan
> 
> On Wed, Dec 5, 2012 at 9:36 AM, Jonathan Taylor <
> jonathan.taylor@stanford.edu> wrote:
> 
> > Hey Fernando,
> > 
> > Well, I think Rstudio depends on knitr in order to enable their nice
> > reports:
> > 
> > http://www.rstudio.com/ide/docs/authoring/using_markdown
> > http://www.rstudio.com/ide/docs/r_markdown
> > 
> > So, if we want it to enable something like a cell-based interactive
> > version of Rstudio (where one executes a cell at the time instead of
> > producing the entire pdf file as in Rstudio) in the notebook, it is the
> > easiest approach. I think it would feel most natural to Rstudio users.
> > 
> > Two things I don't like about the current R magic is:
> > - To get output one has to call print so it doesn't feel like using the R
> >   console.
> > - If you don't explicitly ask for no return, rpy2 returns the "last
> >   object" in the interpreter -- this is R's default behaviour but feels
> >   very
> >   unpythonic.
> > 
> > For example:
> > 
> > > f = function() {
> > > - Z = rnorm(1)
> > > - Z
> > > - }
> > > 
> > > f()
> > > [1] 1.318857
> > > 
> > > g = function() {
> > > - Z = rnorm(1)
> > > - }
> > >   g()
> > 
> > In python, neither of these functions would return anything because there
> > is no return statement. In R, it somehow guesses you wanted to return Z
> > in
> > the function f.
> > 
> > So, with the knitr version, I want the %R magics to not return anything
> > by
> > default but it could return a dictionary of variables based on the -o
> > flags. Right now, the -o flag sets the variable in the ipython namespace.
> > 
> > Jonathan
> > 
> > On Wed, Dec 5, 2012 at 12:53 AM, Fernando Perez <
> > Fernando.Perez@berkeley.edu> wrote:
> > 
> > > sorry, I'm in Hawaii with a broken laptop and hence near-zero
> > > connectivity (and no way to do any work beyond typing 3-line replies).
> > > 
> > > I haven't caught up with any ipython public work in the last few
> > > weeks, but I'll do so once I get back.
> > > 
> > > but I did look briefly at it a while ago and I worrry about adding a
> > > knitr dependency.  it's kind of nice that the R magics 'just work'
> > > with a base R install. How critical is knitr, and how feasible would
> > > it be to have basic functionality work without?
> > > 
> > > you know how it goes: every new dependency slashes your user base in
> > > half, they say :)
> > > 
> > > best
> > > 
> > > f
> > > 
> > > On 12/4/12, Jonathan Taylor jonathan.taylor@stanford.edu wrote:
> > > 
> > > > Hey Fernando,
> > > > 
> > > > I was wondering if you ever had a chance to look at the pull request
> > > > for R
> > > > to use knitr. It seemed there was an objection that it depended on the
> > > > knitr package in R, but I modified it to allow it not use knitr.
> > > > 
> > > > I hate to bug you about it, but just think this would be an
> > > > improvement
> > > > and
> > > > haven't heard anything about it.
> > > > 
> > > > Thanks,
> > > > 
> > > > Jonathan
Hi, just saw your new commits, unfortunately this does not merge cleany. Also I'm not an R User so I'm not really in a good position to review...

Playing with this PR a little, my first impression is that the error reporting from knitr is much better than that with the current IPython code.

With the old code, when you have a large block of R code with a syntax error, it's very hard to find your error. With this PR though, the messages are much better:

```
RRuntimeError: Error in parse(text = x, srcfile = src) : <text>:3:21: unexpected symbol
2: p = ggplot(data.frame(x=x, y=x^2), aes(x,y))
3: p = p + geom_line() syntax_error
                      ^
```

For me (an R novice that makes lots of bugs), this alone is a huge win.

---

The PR mentions using `?` to get help, but I had a little trouble with that. The help output comes, but then I'm also getting a python error.

This cell for instance:

```
%%R
?lm
```

Produces:

```

R Help on 'lm'lm                    package:stats                    R Documentation

_ F_ i_ t_ t_ i_ n_ g _ L_ i_ n_ e_ a_ r _ M_ o_ d_ e_ l_ s

_ D_ e_ s_ c_ r_ i_ p_ t_ i_ o_ n:

     'lm' is used to fit linear models.  It can be used to carry out
     regression, single stratum analysis of variance and analysis of
     covariance (although 'aov' may provide a more convenient interface
     for these).

[..snip...]

     opar <- par(mfrow = c(2,2), oma = c(0, 0, 1.1, 0))
     plot(lm.D9, las = 1)      # Residuals, Fitted, ...
     par(opar)

     ### less simple examples in "See Also" above

    `?`(lm)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
UnboundLocalError                         Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-14-9de0d21a54a2> in <module>()
----> 1 get_ipython()._run_cached_cell_magic(u'R', u'')

   2116             magic_arg_s = self.var_expand(line, stack_depth)
```

Just testing this out:

A few quibbles about the warning message about knitr - it's not clear to users who don't know what knitr is, the solution offered doesn't work in IPython, and the warning system produces ugly formatting. I suggest:

```
print("To get the best output from R, we recommend installing knitr. You can do this in IPython with %Rinstall knitr")
```

Without knitr, simple things seem to work, but attempting a plot displays a big ugly traceback: https://gist.github.com/4478972 . The same plot works with the current implementation of rmagic.

With knitr, the plot works, and... %%R echoes the R code, then precedes each output line with `##`. I assume I'm missing something here? R exceptions still seem to come underneath a big Python traceback, and the `?` help has the same error that @rmcgibbo pointed out. I've uploaded the notebook so you can see what I tried: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/gist.github.com/raw/4479164/b432b905512a3407b71d9c6f12464ab641947533/knitr.ipynb

Also, don't forget that this needs rebasing on master. I've just checked, there are a couple of small conflicts that should be easy to resolve.

@jonathan-taylor, sorry again for the long delay!  

We're all warming up the engines again and revisiting this, let us know if you need a hand with the rebase and I'll be happy to help out.  I promise that we won't let this one linger anymore, so if you have bandwidth to address the comments above and fix up the rebasing/conflicts, we should be able to make quick progress.

This PR has been sitting for a while now and is a candidate to close:

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/wiki/Dev:-Closing-pull-requests

Are we waiting for more code?  Further review?  If we are waiting for more code, I would like to close this and open an issue to track the progress of this work.
I tried to review it, but I couldn't see any advantage over the current system. I assume I must be missing something, but I'm waiting for clarification on that.
I would like to close this PR because of inactivity and open an issue to track progress.  Is everyone OK with that?  If/when work start up again we can re-open it.
Closing this PR due to inactivity.  I have opened an issue to track the work: #3169.  Feel free to reopen this PR if work starts up again.
